Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Ripon Energy has a well-developed and fully implemented Safety Program Library, inclusive of 34 plus Programs and associated subordinate procedures, forms, etc.  Elements of the library are reviewed when regulations change, when team members identify deficiencies, and in the event of an incident.

Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) 
Ripon Energy uses an integrated MOC / PSSR procedure to safely and efficiently manage changes to the Covered Process.

Compliance Audits 
Ripon Energy conducts audits for compliance with EPA RMP, CalARP, and California Process Safety Management Standard requirements at least once every three years.

Incident Investigation 
Ripon Energy investigates all incidents and near-miss events.

Employee Participation 
Ripon Energy solicits and (in some cases) requires the participation of employees in the advancement of the RMP program.  At least one employee has direct involvement in the PHA process.  Ripon Energy employees have access to all CalARP/RMP documentation.

Hot Work Permits 
Ripon Energy's fully implemented Safety Program Library includes a Hot Work Permit Program.

Contractor Safety 
Ripon Energy's fully implemented Safety Program Library includes a Onsite Persons Management Program.

Emergency Action Plan 
Ripon Energy does not have an Emergency Response Plan; the facility coordinates with Ripon Fire District (the community Emergency Response provider) with which it has a continuing working relationship.  However, Ripon Energy's fully implemented Safety Program Library includes an Emergency Action Plan Program, which is reviewed periodically.  The Emergency Action Plan gives guidance and specific action to be taken in response to accidental releases, directs all public communications to management, and includes information on emergency health care.

Training 
Ripon Energy provides documented initial and refresher training for employees conducting activities involved in the maintenance and operation of the Covered Process and consults with employees about the frequency of training.

Record Keeping 
Ripon Energy maintains RMP implementation records for five years.

Process Safety Information (PSI)

impacts, offsite response, and corrective measures.

Level 3 Prevention Program
Ripon Energy implements a Prevention Program consistent with Level 3 requirements.  The Prevention Program includes:

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) 
Ripon Energy conducts Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at least every five years to identify, evaluate, and control the risk associated with process hazards or chemical release scenarios involving the Covered Process.  The most recent PHA utilized the hazard and operability (HAZOP) and What If/Checklist methodologies.  Action Items are tracked to completion in Program documents.

Operating Procedures 
Ripon Energy maintains written procedures to operate systems in the Covered Process that include operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems functionality.  Applicable Operating Procedures are reviewed, updated, and certified annually or when changes are made to the Ammonia System.  Revisions are documented in the version history of the procedure.

Safe Work Practices 
Ripon Energy maintains written Safety Programs to ensure Safe Work.  These programs include:  Training Program; Safety Observation Program; Incident Management Program; Onsite Persons Management Program; First Aid/CPR/AED Program; Bloodborne Pathogens Program; PPE Program; Respiratory Protection Program; Safe Work Program, including Work Permits, Job Hazard Analyses, and Job Briefings; LOTO Program; Hot Work Program; Haz Mat / Haz Com / WHMIS Program; and HazMat Hazardous Substances Management Program.

Mechanical Integrity (MI) 
Ripon Energy maintains Mechanical Integrity practices to ensure continued integrity of the Covered Process equipment by maintaining, inspecting, and testing Covered Process equipment consistent with manufacturers' recommendations and good engineering practices.  The MI practices include inventory of process equipment; process and instrumentation diagrams; maintenance, inspection, and testing schedules; and maintenance documentati

Certification 
Ripon Energy's RMP Program is certified by informed and qualified individuals to be true in its content and implemented to the best of the facility's capabilities.

Risk Management Plan Overview
AltaGas Ripon Energy Inc. (Ripon Energy) owns and operates an electricity generation facility (facility) at 944 South Stockton Ave., Ripon, California in San Joaquin County, California, in an area of primarily light industrial use.
Ripon Energy's Covered Process is the Ammonia System, which uses Refrigeration Grade (99+ %) anhydrous ammonia (CAS No. 7664 41 7) (1) as the refrigerant in an Ammonia Refrigeration System, also known as a Gas Turbine Inlet Air Chiller (Chiller) System and (2) as a reactant for NOx emissions reduction in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) System.

General Requirements
Ripon Energy's RMP is RMP Program Level 3.
Ripon Energy maintains a Management System that assigns responsibilities and resources for implementing EPA and CalARP/RMP provisions.
EPA RMP Registration Information is included in the Program.
Ripon Energy submits to EPA via RMP*eSubmit as required.
Ripon Energy updates and corrects the RMP per regulation.  Ripon Energy also follows the regulation for Covered Process Modifications.

Hazard Assessment
Ripon Energy performs Hazard Assessment which includes Two Toxic Worst-Case Release Scenario analyses and two Toxic Alternative Release Scenarios.
The scenarios include Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA), per RMP EPA OCA Guidance, that provides definition of Offsite Impacts to the Population and Offsite Impacts to the Environment, including distances to Toxic Endpoints.
Ripon Energy reviews and updates the OCA at least once every five years or more frequently as defined in the regulation.

Five-Year Accident History
Ripon Energy has had zero accidental releases in the five-year period preceding the date of this document.
